title: Static files on HackerOne.com can be made inaccessible through Cache Poisoning attack

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
## Summary:

Hi,

The host hackerone.com uses cloudlfare to cache static files. The header x-forwarded-scheme can be used to cause a redirect loop, which will be cached by cloudflare. By taking down a JS file, it is possible to  cause a total loss of availability on hackerone.com 

### Disclaimer

No actual denial of service attack was caused in my testing. All the testing used cache-busters, meaning it did not affect the live website in any way

## Steps To Reproduce

1.  Send the following request:

```http
GET /assets/static/js/8.9572d249.chunk.js?hackerone=poc HTTP/2
Host: hackerone.com
x-forwarded-scheme: http

```

make sure to use a get parameter as a cachebuster

2.  You should notice a 301 redirect to the same page. Since the redirect poins to the same exact page, it will not be a redirect loop. The 301 is cached and removing the header will show the same redirect loop. 


### Video PoC

 ████

## Impact

The same attack that was reproduced on `/assets/static/js/8.9572d249.chunk.js?hackerone=poc` could be reproduced on the actual file without any random parameter. This would cause the file to no longer be accessible, hence causing a DoS on any pages relying on that js file. This works on any file that is cached on hackerone.com/*, including images, css files, js files  etc. Other than js files that would make the page unusuable, an attacker could also make images unavailable, etc.

activities.message:
Hello @youstin,

This seems to work only for me. My colleagues were not affected by the looped redirection. Can you please double check it?

Regards,
@turtle_shell

Hi @turtle_shell 

When poisoning cloudflare caches you have to look at the CF-RAY header. Not all worldwide users connect to the same cache, and CF-RAY indicates which cache gave you the response. For example, the following CF-RAY headear value will indicate responses are passed by the Amsterdam Server:

`Cf-Ray: 6498c2c958e89cee-AMS`
AMS = Amsterdam

If you and your colleagues do not live in a simillar area, you might be talking to different caches. I attached a video PoC where I used multipe IPs from both Romania and the Netherlands and showed I was hitting the same cached response. If I were to try requesting that from the USA, the request wouldnt have been poisoned.

### Video PoC:

██████

This shouldn't however raise the attack's CVSS complexity. Cloudflare and other CDNs publish their ips online, so itterating through them and poisoning a multitude of caches is a one line job. This concept has also been discussed by researchers such as albinowax, in Practical Web Cache Poisoning, under the Cross-Cloud Poisoning section.

Taken from [Practical Web Cache Poisoning](https://portswigger.net/research/practical-web-cache-poisoning)

{F1286822}

Hi @turtle_shell ,

It’s been 9 days since I reported this. Is there any reason for the delay here?

Thanks

Hi @turtle_shell

thanks for the meme :D I just wanted to make sure this hasn't been forgotten about. Let me know if you need any more information from my side before triaging it.

Hi @youstin, thanks again for your report.

To prevent your hopes from getting up, I do want to point out that Denial of Service vulnerabilities are currently out of scope, per the the Scope Exclusions on https://hackerone.com/security

I do think this is an interesting issue though and looks like something that shouldn't be happening. I'll be working with Cloudflare and try to get clear on why this redirect loop is occurring, as this appears to be an issue in their caching stack.

Thus far I haven't been able to find what the `x-forwarded-scheme` header is exactly doing and why this would cause the redirect loop. Do you have any thoughts?

Regards,
Tom

Another things I wanted to point out or get more information on, is how you think this issue could be exploited? 

In your report you mention making the javascript assets unavailable by requesting them with the `x-forwarded-scheme: http` header set. While I agree you can cause a redirect loop on an asset file with the cache buster key set, it will be really hard to pull this off on the actual javascript asset, as it will most likely already be cached by Cloudflare correctly. Giving the number of requests performed against the javascript asset, I believe it will be very hard to actually perform the first request (with the `x-forwarded-scheme` header) on the uncached version of the asset, making it unavailable.

Do you agree this makes the impact of the vulnerability a lot lower?

Hi @tomdev 

Regarding Denial of Service being out of scope, I see it has been temporarily removed from scope since June 2020th. I am not sure why hackerone decided to do so, but I am guessing a number of users were causing too may requests. The report I sent was confirmed without any strain to the h1 server's and without affeting the live website in any way. This is not a typical DoS attack, since it does not rely on resource exhaustion or simillar issues. Hence, this has been previously reported by Albinowax, with a slightly different impact (  it only affected redirects, not static files), and it has been triaged and fixed by the h1 team.
I doubt this is the type of vulnerability h1 wanted to no longer be reported. Morevoer, since this is marked as temporarily, I doubt h1 would prefer me to wait until that is adjusted, leaving the webstie exposed to this attack.

I am not sure what caused the 301 redirect, however I have reproduced it on other cdns too, such as akamai, so I am not sure if its a cloudflare issue. 

> Giving the number of requests performed against the javascript asset, I believe it will be very hard to actually perform the first request (with the x-forwarded-scheme header) on the uncached version of the asset, making it unavailable.

This statement is not entirely accurate. Considering we know the cache age by looking at the Age header and we know the max-age, timing an attack can be easily achieved. Moreover, using a tool such as burp's turbo intruder, would make sending thousands of requests in the span of a secnod trivial, hence poisoning the cache will not be a challenging task. It's also worth nothing that this affetcs all static files.Writing a script to monitor the age header on all files, could easily allow for DoS attacks across the hackerone website.

Taking that into consideration, I propose this CVSS would describe the issue accurately:

CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H

The nature of the attack does make the complexity high, however the Availability should also still be high.

Hey @youstin, thanks for your patience on this issue. 

It took us some back and forth with Cloudflare and debugging sessions in our application stack to find the culprit. This issue is actually caused by _rack_ middleware that we're using. Specifically the following code:
```ruby
    def forwarded_scheme
      allowed_scheme(get_header(HTTP_X_FORWARDED_SCHEME)) ||
      allowed_scheme(extract_proto_header(get_header(HTTP_X_FORWARDED_PROTO)))
    end
```
From: https://github.com/rack/rack/blob/a72d8b0661257517e89dd08ffadfeb23f407a8bc/lib/rack/request.rb#L626

The `X-Forwarded-Proto` header is set correctly in our case (always set to "https"), but as you can tell from the code snippet the `X-Forwarded-Scheme` header is taking precedence, and will be used as the scheme for the request.

We've deployed a fix to production to prevent the `X-Forwarded-Scheme` header from getting used, so it should not be possible to cache poison the assets anymore. Could you validate this?

Hi @tomdev,

It's great to hear that you found the root issue of this, since I also noticed this in a few other Ruby on Rails applications, but wasn't able to pinpoint what exactly was causing it.  

I tried reproducing the Cache Poisoning again, however I was not able to. I tried different values to both `x-forwaded-scheme` and `x-forwarded-proto`, but neither caused a redirect, so the issue seems to be fixed.

Let me know if you need any other information, iustin.
Triaging to put it in the right state since we did investigation and implemented a fix.
@youstin thanks for retesting, let me do the platform retesting so we have the record there as well!

I tried reproducing the Cache Poisoning again, however I was not able to. I tried different values to both x-forwaded-scheme and x-forwarded-proto, but neither caused a redirect, so the issue seems to be fixed.
Thank you for confirming! We'll be making a bounty decision in the next few days, thanks for your patience!

Hi @youstin - thanks again for bringing this to our attention! We're reducing the severity to a Medium since this the cache poisoning vulnerability you found only affected a subset of users accessing HackerOne.com, namely users that had a cache-miss. It would not crash a HackerOne system and an emergency mitigation (disable caching) would've limited the actual downtime for users.

additional_data.old_title: Cache Poisoning DoS on hackerone.com static files
additional_data.new_title: Static files on HackerOne.com can be made inaccessible through Cache Poisoning attack

activities.message: Hi @youstin - thanks again for bringing this to our attention, it's much appreciated!

Hi @jobert,

Thanks for the bounty! 

Regarding the statement:

> only affected a subset of users accessing HackerOne.com, namely users that had a cache-miss

This is actually the complete opposite. If a user would get a cache-miss, their request would be forwarded to the origin server, populating the cache with the correct javascrpt file. 
With caching servers, all users in a region talk to the same cache.  This means that if I get a cache-miss, the response to my request will be forwarded to everyone else in the region for a long period of time. While my 301 response is cached, other users will not get a cache miss, since the cache will always respond with my poisoned response. Therefore, the impacted users are not the subset that had a cache-miss, but the users that are in the same region of the attacker. 
Since cloudflare publishes it's IP ranges publicly, an attacker can route traffic to different caching servers from a single machine. When taking the following into consideration, plus having VPSs in multiple regions,  I believe a well coordinated attack could take down hackerone services for the majority of users. 
Even though this won't change the final severity, I do believe `Availability: High` would be better suited here.

Hi @youstin - obviously you're right. I meant to say cache-hit, not cache-miss. Apologies for the confusion. I'm afraid we'll have to agree to disagree when it comes to severity though - we'd like to keep a High impact on Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability for more widespread issues than the one you've reported. We don't believe that this issue causes a total loss of availability.

Hi @youstin - to clarify for you and others when this report is public: we ended up awarding a bounty for the vulnerability because this was a cache poisoning vulnerability and not a DoS vulnerability, which are still out of scope at this time. Thanks again for bringing this to our attention, it's much appreciated!

Hi @jobert 

I was hoping to release a write-up on a few of my cache poisoning reports, ( including this one ), but it is unfortunately taking other programs a bit longer to fix the issues I reported. I'd appreciate if we could postpone disclosure here up until other programs have fixed the issues I reported. Would it be ok If I we disclose once all programs have resolved it and I have the write-up ready?
Hi @youstin - yeah, no problem. Just let us know when you're ready!

Hi @jobert,

I am hoping to publish my the write-up this upcoming week, so could you please request disclosure again? This would make it easier for me to disclose the report once I have everything ready.

Thanks a lot, 
Youstin.
